oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. Her ancestors included the Scott, Deaderick, Crozier, Ramsey, Anderson and Alexander families. Francis Alexander Ramsey Scott (1827-1909) married Margaretta Frances Deaderick (1833-1909) in 1857. They were the parents of eleven children, including daughter Miss Edith Scott (1878-1971). Caption information appears below in the Full Text field.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a log house, later weatherboarded, built by my grandfather, James Scott, Sr. on the site of a filling station on the corner of Broadway and Lawson Streets, Knoxville, Tennessee. He was born in Ireland, and we first hear of him in Virginia, where he married Janet Adams, daughter of John and Agnes Adams. They moved to Washington County (then in North Carolina):, then to Blount County, where their first years were spent in a blockhouse, after which he built a log house on his farm which consisted of 640 acres, but at one time they were forced to return to the blockhouse, because of an Indian raid. He, with other men, fired through the portholes while Janet and other women moulded bullets on the hearth. He was an intrepid fighter, John Sevier called him his "right-hand man" when fighting the Indians. I am pretty sure he fought with John Sevier in the Battle of King's Mountain, but have never been able to prove it. He and Janet were members of the New Providence Presbyterian Church in Blount County and moved their membership September 22, 1821 to the First Presbyterian Church of Knoxville, Tennessee. James and Janet Adams Scott are buried in the old graveyard of that church. They both were born in the year 1760. He died August 30, 1823:, aged 63 years. Janet died August 10, 183 7, aged 77 years. Ramsey's Annals tells of James Scott Sr. being a representative from Blount County to the House of Representatives, and also tells of his receiving a letter from his brother-in-law, Samuel Handley (Henley). They married sisters, Samue I Henley married Mary Adams, and James Scott, Sr. married Janet Adams. Janet (more often called Jane) Adams Scott, a sprightly vivacious little soul with auburn hair, was born in Virginia, but was of Irish ancestry. Her son, James Scott, Jr. spoke of her as his "sweet little Irish mother" and said she spoke with an Irish brogue. Her experiences as a pioneer woman were ever vivid in her mind, and when telling them, she would walk the floor, dropping her knitting ball, her little grandson (my father) would pick it up, trembling with fear and excitement as she told her narrow escapes from the Indians. This picture was taken by "Sister Ret" who could draw and paint as life-like pictures as the ones she took with her camera. (continued inside)
